linkTarget.anchoringText: Kuwait Oil Company (KOC) has been producing oil from the Upper Burgan formation for over 60 years from the Raudhatain and Sabriyah oil fields of North Kuwait (Figure 1). Both fields are essentially very large dome shaped anticlines that have been highly faulted and are structurally complex. Raudhatain Upper Burgan is North Kuwait’s prolific producer under active water flood as well as with natural edge water drive. It’s a mature Reservoir with water cut all over the field but still with lot of production potential.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Location map of Raudhatain Oil Field, State of Kuwait

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location map of Raudhatain Oil Field, State of Kuwait

linkTarget.anchoringText: Raudhatain Upper Burgan (UB) is a multilayer clastic reservoir in North Kuwait under active waterflood since 2000. With four major flow units, poor sweep efficiency often results from spatial variation and/or heterogeneity in the permeability of the reservoir rock. These major and well-known different units, prevent the conventional analysis of Voidage Replacement Ratio (VRR) as other conventional reservoirs (Figure 2). The initial completion design did not address the injection profile control and the majority of water was going to the unit UB5.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Ghapical representation of the five major units.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Ghapical representation of the five major units.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Upper Burgan Formation is the uppermost unit of the Burgan Formation. The Burgan Formation was deposited during the Albian period (Early Cretaceous) time and it is overlain by Mauddud Formation and underlain by Shuaiba Formation (Figure 3). The Upper Burgan reservoir is encountered at vertical depths of ~ 7600 feet at the crest of the structure in the Raudhatain field. The Upper Burgan reservoir in the Raudhatain field is approximately 160 feet thickness and the thickness varies in different parts of the field.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Stratigraphic section (Upper Burgan)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Stratigraphic section (Upper Burgan)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Upper Burgan is represented by two end member depositional models in the Raudhatain field. These are a fluvial dominated, tidally influenced delta and a marine influenced shoreface model (Figure 4 & 5). In the Raudhatain Field four major stratigraphic surfaces have been identified and these are regarded as flooding surfaces or transgressive surfaces that can be correlated on a field wide basis. These stratigraphic surfaces separate the four clastic intervals that have been identified as the UB2, UB3, UB4, and UB5 layers. These clastic layers are the oil producing zones.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: High clastic influx during phases of sea-level fall/low sea-level resulting in major phases of delta build out

formatted-caption.caption-text: High clastic influx during phases of sea-level fall/low sea-level resulting in major phases of delta build out

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Upper Burgan is represented by two end member depositional models in the Raudhatain field. These are a fluvial dominated, tidally influenced delta and a marine influenced shoreface model (Figure 4 & 5). In the Raudhatain Field four major stratigraphic surfaces have been identified and these are regarded as flooding surfaces or transgressive surfaces that can be correlated on a field wide basis. These stratigraphic surfaces separate the four clastic intervals that have been identified as the UB2, UB3, UB4, and UB5 layers. These clastic layers are the oil producing zones.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: More marine-influenced shoreline conditions characterised by relative sea-level rise / High sea-level and localized, low rates of clastic influx

formatted-caption.caption-text: More marine-influenced shoreline conditions characterised by relative sea-level rise / High sea-level and localized, low rates of clastic influx

linkTarget.anchoringText: We can see from this typical Raudhatain well (Figure 6) that the UB5 and UB4 layers appear to be coarsening upwards sequences that represent the more marine shoreface deposits. The UB3 and UB2 layers however are thicker and often exhibit blocky or fining upwards sequences. These deposits are the fluvial dominated delta channel facies and are the highest reservoir quality rocks in the Upper Burgan Formation. The reservoir quality varies and is largely dependent on the rock type and depositional facies.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Type log of Raudhatain Upper Burgan Reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Type log of Raudhatain Upper Burgan Reservoir

linkTarget.anchoringText: In order to manage the production, water flooding has been started in this reservoir since (2000) as a pilot, which was expanded in 2002 with seawater injection. Meanwhile, with the demand of pressure support and increasing number of producers, a new project in Upper Burgan for Effluent Water System has been started in 2014. Currently the injectors meet allowable that was specified based on simulation modeling target for Upper Burgan and it is approximately 200 MBWPD. The current injection profile & liquid production trend in Upper Burgan are shown in (Figure 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Current injection and Liquid Rate

formatted-caption.caption-text: Current injection and Liquid Rate

linkTarget.anchoringText: This type of simple horizontal wells (Figure 8), cemented and selectively perforated, do not have control over water production which leads to unswept bypassed oil. To have control over water movement, to have uniform sweep and to avoid heel to toe effect it was decided to complete all horizontal wells with ICD. Passive inflow control device was installed in all the newly drilled wells (Figure 9).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Horizontal Well: Cased and Perforated

formatted-caption.caption-text: Horizontal Well: Cased and Perforated

linkTarget.anchoringText: This type of simple horizontal wells (Figure 8), cemented and selectively perforated, do not have control over water production which leads to unswept bypassed oil. To have control over water movement, to have uniform sweep and to avoid heel to toe effect it was decided to complete all horizontal wells with ICD. Passive inflow control device was installed in all the newly drilled wells (Figure 9).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Horizontal well: Open hole with Passive ICD completion

formatted-caption.caption-text: Horizontal well: Open hole with Passive ICD completion

linkTarget.anchoringText: The average instantaneous Voidage Replacement Ratio till year 2012 was only 0.25 with the help of four sea water injection phase 1 wells. Through fast track action plan five injectors added to injection system resulted in Voidage Replacement Ratio increase to 0.7. Presently the VRR is being maintained about one after commissioning four effluent water injection wells on August 2014. The below Figure 10 shows the historical VRR performance of the field.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Non-Conventional well: Slant with SS ICD / AICD

formatted-caption.caption-text: Non-Conventional well: Slant with SS ICD / AICD

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Figure 11 show the Isobar map of year 2013 and 2015. Recently recorded static bottom hole pressure used in the construction isobar and compared with pressure map of year 2014. The data used are collected from many sources like static bottom hole recording, ESP sensor reading during pump shutdown and RFT measurement. All the collected pressure data were converted to datum. The dark and light blue color in year 2013 map indicates area below bubble point and near bubble point pressure respectively.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Map showing Fast track injectors and other injectors

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map showing Fast track injectors and other injectors

linkTarget.anchoringText: The daily measurement of ESP pump intake pressure measurement shows gradual increase in pressure after commissioning of injectors. It indicated good connectivity between injector and producers (Fig 12).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: RAUB Voidage Replacement Ratio performance

formatted-caption.caption-text: RAUB Voidage Replacement Ratio performance

linkTarget.anchoringText: Before water injection the production was declining at the rate of about 27%. After achieving voidage replacement ratio of 1, the production decline come to an acceptable level of 8% (Fig 13)

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Comparing ISOBAR map for year 2013 and 2015

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparing ISOBAR map for year 2013 and 2015

linkTarget.anchoringText: After producing cumulative oil of about MMbbls water cut increased to 100 % in well xxx. Production logging showed that the most of water is being produced from single layer. The subsequent water shutoff job isolated the water producing layer and put the well back on production with negligible water cut. The successful conformance control resulted in an oil again of about 1800 bpd (Fig 14).

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Impact of water injection shown by increasing pump intake pressure (PIP) Well RA-AA Well RA-BB Well RA-CC

formatted-caption.caption-text: Impact of water injection shown by increasing pump intake pressure (PIP) Well RA-AA Well RA-BB Well RA-CC

linkTarget.anchoringText: The increase in production is attributed to Field Development’s aggressive approach of drilling horizontal/Multilateral wells coupled with ICD / SS ICD / ACID and installing more number of ESP’s. Starting from the year 2004 to 2009 the oil production was stabilized at 35 MBOPD, then production started increasing with the installation ESP’s and now the record level of production is achieved with the drilling number of Non-Conventional Wells. The Fig 15 shows the Production and Pressure performance of RAUB.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Reduction in production decline after water injection

formatted-caption.caption-text: Reduction in production decline after water injection

linkTarget.anchoringText: The basic principle of WFR is from old Watermann patent form the 50’s. One piston is moveable and the other one is fixed as shown in Figure 16 with the size variable depending on the flow desired to be injected in that certain layer so the regulator is calibrated by predetermined flow rate.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Successful water conformance and oil gain

formatted-caption.caption-text: Successful water conformance and oil gain

linkTarget.anchoringText: Therfore, WFR would enable the operator to choke back injection rates in specific layers irrespective of the reservoir pressure, permeability, skin damage or any other factors that would normally affect flow. Each layer or zone is packed off to prevent any fluids within that zone of the wellbore invading another zone. An injection nozzle is located within each section. Several companies currently sell these valves based on the same principle. Figure 17 and 18 show some valves from one of these providers, normally the service include the valves and the tool for the instalation in the mandrel.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Diagram of Watermann theory.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Diagram of Watermann theory.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Therfore, WFR would enable the operator to choke back injection rates in specific layers irrespective of the reservoir pressure, permeability, skin damage or any other factors that would normally affect flow. Each layer or zone is packed off to prevent any fluids within that zone of the wellbore invading another zone. An injection nozzle is located within each section. Several companies currently sell these valves based on the same principle. Figure 17 and 18 show some valves from one of these providers, normally the service include the valves and the tool for the instalation in the mandrel.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Water Flooding Regulator valves and Kick over tools.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water Flooding Regulator valves and Kick over tools.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Completion Considerations (Figure 19):

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Water Flooding Regulator valves. Some models.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water Flooding Regulator valves. Some models.

linkTarget.anchoringText: RA-X injector well is located on the crest area of RA field as shown in Figure 20. It was completed in 2014 with conventional one packer completion to inject into three reservoir layers. Initially, the well was perforated in UB-2, UB-3, UB-4 and UB-5 but unfortunately, more than 75 % of the total injected water was being going into UB-3 based on ILT (Figure 21).

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: WFR completion consideration

formatted-caption.caption-text: WFR completion consideration

linkTarget.anchoringText: RA-X injector well is located on the crest area of RA field as shown in Figure 20. It was completed in 2014 with conventional one packer completion to inject into three reservoir layers. Initially, the well was perforated in UB-2, UB-3, UB-4 and UB-5 but unfortunately, more than 75 % of the total injected water was being going into UB-3 based on ILT (Figure 21).

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: Location of the pilot well.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location of the pilot well.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Step Rate Injectivity Test (SRIT) was done in two zones before installing the regulators. The aim of this test is to determine Formation Parting Pressure (FPP) so as to create fractures and channels prior to installing WFR valves. Figure 22 shows four plots, in the left side, the pressure and rate for the pump and in the right side the well-known SRIT plot for each layer.

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: ILT before WFR

formatted-caption.caption-text: ILT before WFR

linkTarget.anchoringText: The first implementation of WFR in Raudhatain Filed has proved the concept of improving vertical injection profile by enabling higher injection rates into layers that never received water before and regulating the distribution into all layers. As most of the water injected into the well (more than 70%) was traversing through one zone only before the job, the vertical distribution of injected water due to WFR approach resulted in choking the flow through this layer to about 60% and improve the flow through the remaining uncontacted layers like summirized in Table 1 and Figure 23.

image-wrap.label: Figure 23
image-wrap.caption: Analysis of SRIT performed[RAJ10]. Zone 1 Zone 2

formatted-caption.caption-text: Analysis of SRIT performed[RAJ10]. Zone 1 Zone 2

linkTarget.anchoringText: In order to monitor the benefit, a survaillance plan was defined to track that increase of production and reserves by performing frequent PGOR tests and scheduling for PLT for the producers. Some of the preliminary well-testing showed increase of oil production after installing the WFR. In addition to that, monitoring the pump intake preussure as shown in Figure 24 was very important to see if reservoir pressure will increase in the offset producers.

image-wrap.label: Figure 24
image-wrap.caption: First ILT job done after water injection stabilization.

formatted-caption.caption-text: First ILT job done after water injection stabilization.

image-wrap.caption: Performance of pressure of the nearby wells
